>> Joyce: Hi, this
is Joyce Farrell.
Let's finish talking about
the program development cycle.
In the last two videos, you learned
that when a programmer develops
a program the first step is
to understand the
problem and we talked
about a number doubling program
that lets a user type in a value
and find out what 2
times the value is.
We then looked at
planning the logic,
and when we planned the logic,
we looked at 2 tools: a flowchart
and pseudocode, both of
which express the logic
of the program.
In both of these, the user is
allowed to input a number,
the answer is computed
as the number times 2,
and then the answer is output.
After the logic is planned,
you can write the code
in a computer programming
language, and we looked
at an example written in Java.
After the code is written, you
use a compiler or an interpreter
to translate that
code into 1s and 0s,
it becomes machine language
or the internal circuitry
language of the computer.
When the program is successfully
translated, you can test
the program.
Testing the program involves
executing it several times
to make sure that the
output is correct.
For example, with the Java
program, one way to run it is
to go to the Command
Prompt and type java
and the name of the program.
When you hit Enter, you see
the prompt that was part
of the program, Enter a number
and 2 little right-facing
arrows.
You might type a 7 and when
you hit Enter, the output is the
Answer is 14. That's correct
and you have one successful
test of the program.
An experienced programmer knows
that you had better test
the program many more times
to make sure it's correct
with other values as well,
so you might run the program
again and type in 124.
If the answer comes up 248, you
become increasingly confident
that this program does, indeed,
double numbers that
the user inputs.
You would then run the program
many more times and, finally,
you would be satisfied
that it is correct.
After the program has
been tested, you can put it
into production.
Putting it into production
means turning it
over to the clients
who will use it.
It might also involve
training the clients.
You might hold a class for
them in how to use the program.
You might publish a booklet for
them on how to use the program.
It might involve all sorts
of tasks to turn it over
and make it a viable program.
After a program is in production,
over time you may need
to maintain the program.
For example, suppose your
user comes to you and says,
"You know the number doubling
program has been working great,
but the other day
something terrible happened.
We were running the program
and it said enter a number
and a user typed in 7, s-e-v-e-n.
The user pressed the Enter key,
and, oh my goodness, all these
error messages appeared
and we didn't know what to do."
Well, the problem,
if you can read
that first error message
line and kind of figure
out what it means it says,
"InputMismatchException."
The problem is the
user typed a word
and the program was
only expecting a digit.
You might handle this
in any number of ways.
You might change the prompt
to say something like,
"Enter a number and make sure
it's a digit and not a word."
You might instead allow
the user to enter a word,
but change the word
into a number internally
in the program.
You might handle the problem
in any number of ways.
It's up to your client
what they want you to do.
But making the changes that
are necessary is maintaining
the program.
Over time your client may come
to you and say, "You know,
we'd like some more
changes to this program."
For example, what
if the client wants
to let the user multiply
any 2 values, not just 2
but maybe triple or
quadruple any value?
Or suppose the client says,
"You know, this program is
so successful let's start
charging money, and I want you
to keep track of the
money the user owes us
and let's let the user put
the fee on a credit card,
so add that capability
to the program."
And, of course, if the
user's going to put the fee
on a credit card, let's
have the program dial
into the credit card company
and make sure the user has money
available on a credit card.
And, you know, our good users,
after they use the program 10
times, let's give them a discount
and not charge $.10
per use but only $.08,
and so on and so on and so on."
And the user might have
so many new requirements
that you might say,
"Wait a minute,
there's so many issues here, I
better understand the problem
all over again and
let's sit down and talk
about all the changes
that need to be made."
And when you understand the
new problem, you might then want
to plan the logic for the
new program, write its code,
translate that code into machine
language, then test the new
program and see if it
works correctly, and put it
into production with all the new
instructions for the clients.
And over time that new program
may need to be maintained.
And the program development
cycle may continue over
and over again many times
over the life of the program.
Thanks for watching.
